title: How to Give Your Teen's Room a Makeover

steps.headline: Make a plan with your child.
steps.description: Incorporate details that they enjoy (colours, activities, patterns, etc) into the room.

steps.headline: Also, make a floor plan of the furniture layout.
steps.description:
Make sure to include: A bed{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d8\/Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d8\/Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} A dresser or wardrobe A desk with a matching chair A bookshelf A mirror Any other mandatory things you need (guitar stand, rocking chair, etc)

steps.headline: Find things you can give to charity.
steps.description: For example, if your son/daughter has an old toy they never play with, ask them if it's okay to give it to charity. If they say yes, put it in a cardboard box labeled "For Charity". If they say no, keep it. You do not want to get rid of their favourite object.

steps.headline: Find new furniture.
steps.description: Make sure it is small enough to fit in their bedroom. Stereotyped styles are white-painted wood for girls, darker-natural wood for boys. You do not have to stick to those styles, but the furniture showroom probably will have it organized that way.

steps.headline: Clean out that clutter!
Clean the room.
steps.description: Vacuum and/or mop the floors, wash the windows, dust the ceiling fan; Do everything to get that old room clean.

steps.headline: Paint the walls - it will make the overall biggest difference and is still quite cheap.
steps.description: Make sure to choose a color that your child will grow with, because their tastes WILL change. Good colors for each gender can be found in the "Tips" section of this article.

steps.headline: If you are replacing the flooring, do so while the paint is drying.
steps.description: Wood has always been popular, but carpet can be good if your child is clumsy. See "Tips" for more information.

steps.headline: Install new lighting/ ceiling fans.
steps.description: Choose white, a timeless classic, for the ceiling fan paint, and a gender neutral light cover.

steps.headline: Bring in that furniture!
steps.description: Arrange the things you bought like in the floor plan. If you discover that it doesn't work, try another format.

steps.headline: Accessorize, Accessorize, Accessorize!
steps.description: Put up the blinds and curtains (You will need both! ), add the bedding, bring in some lamps that match the room, add some style to the bland, boring, teen-cave.

steps.headline: Put all of the things you kept back into their places.
steps.description: If you redid the closet, place clothes and other associated items into their spots. Add books to the bookshelf. Place treasured toys and stuffed animals in discreet, opaque bins in the bookshelf. Put all of the stuff back.

steps.headline: Have your teen enjoy their new room!

text:
Make a plan with your child. Incorporate details that they enjoy (colours, activities, patterns, etc) into the room. Also, make a floor plan of the furniture layout. Make sure to include: A bed{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d8\/Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d8\/Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} A dresser or wardrobe A desk with a matching chair A bookshelf A mirror Any other mandatory things you need (guitar stand, rocking chair, etc) Find things you can give to charity. For example, if your son/daughter has an old toy they never play with, ask them if it's okay to give it to charity. If they say yes, put it in a cardboard box labeled "For Charity". If they say no, keep it. You do not want to get rid of their favourite object. Find new furniture. Make sure it is small enough to fit in their bedroom. Stereotyped styles are white-painted wood for girls, darker-natural wood for boys. You do not have to stick to those styles, but the furniture showroom probably will have it organized that way. Clean out that clutter! This is the time a basement or storage place comes in handy. Clean this way: Remove all precious items first, like instruments, heirlooms, or stuffed animals. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bc\/Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bc\/Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Give-Your-Teen%27s-Room-a-Makeover-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Put pens, pencils, markers, crayons, hair accessories and brushes, and other small items in labeled plastic bags. Put your clothes, shoes, socks, and other things your child wears in wardrobe boxes that you should put in the basement. Take books, notepads, paper, notebooks, and other paper items to the basement or storage room. Bring toys, video games, DVDs, CDs, and other non-electronic entertainment items to your storage area. Turn off and unplug electronics and lighting and put them in your storage place. Bring your furniture to your storage place. Clean the room. Vacuum and/or mop the floors, wash the windows, dust the ceiling fan; Do everything to get that old room clean. Paint the walls - it will make the overall biggest difference and is still quite cheap. Make sure to choose a color that your child will grow with, because their tastes WILL change. Good colors for each gender can be found in the "Tips" section of this article. If you are replacing the flooring, do so while the paint is drying. Wood has always been popular, but carpet can be good if your child is clumsy. See "Tips" for more information. Install new lighting/ ceiling fans. Choose white, a timeless classic, for the ceiling fan paint, and a gender neutral light cover. Bring in that furniture! Arrange the things you bought like in the floor plan. If you discover that it doesn't work, try another format. Accessorize, Accessorize, Accessorize! Put up the blinds and curtains (You will need both! ), add the bedding, bring in some lamps that match the room, add some style to the bland, boring, teen-cave. Put all of the things you kept back into their places. If you redid the closet, place clothes and other associated items into their spots. Add books to the bookshelf. Place treasured toys and stuffed animals in discreet, opaque bins in the bookshelf. Put all of the stuff back. Have your teen enjoy their new room!
